Sampling

  Course(s)
  Big question



  476, 563, 565
  
    What is the population?
    All US adults? All future nits from a production line? All students with bachelor's degree?  All continuous functions on a given domain?
  



  476, 563, 565
  
    How do we sample from the population?
    Independent and identically distributed (IID)? Low discrepancy (LD)? Stratified sampling? Designed experiment?
  



  476
  
    What can go wrong between intended and actual sampling?
    
      Nonresponse and missingness (informal preview)
      Measurement error
      Coverage error
    
  



Point Estimation

  Course(s)
  Big question



  476, 563
  
    What is the estimand?
    
      Parameter vs functional of a distribution
      What does it mean in context?
      What is random, what is fixed?
    
  



  563
  
    What makes an estimator ‚Äúoptimal‚Äù?
    
      Loss functions and risk
      Invariance/equivariance (as appropriate)
      Benchmarks and lower bounds (when assumptions hold)

section: Academic Integrity, Technology, and AI Usage
text:
Academic Integrity, Technology, and AI Usage
You are encouraged to use technology, including AI tools like ChatGPT, to explore ideas and complete assignments or projects, as long as you understand the work and can explain it yourself. On tests and the final exam, no technology or AI will be allowed unless I say otherwise. Always use these tools to support your learning, not to replace it, and give credit if they meaningfully contribute to your work.
Students are expected to uphold the highest standards of honesty in their academic work, in accordance with Illinois Tech‚Äôs Code of Academic Honesty.

Permitted Use

Assignments & Projects: You are encouraged to use technology and AI tools to assist in problem-solving, exploring concepts, and checking work.
You must critically evaluate AI-generated content for accuracy, completeness, and clarity.
You are responsible for understanding and being able to explain any work produced with technological assistance.



Prohibited Use

Tests & Final Exam: No technology, AI tools, or external resources may be used unless explicitly allowed by the instructor.
Submitting AI-generated or technological outputs without personal understanding is prohibited and will be treated as a violation.



Citations & Transparency
If you use AI tools, software, or other external resources in a way that significantly shapes your work, you must acknowledge it (e.g., ‚ÄúApproach suggested by ChatGPT‚Äù).


Consequences
Violations will be handled according to Illinois Tech‚Äôs Code of Academic Honesty.

title: MATH 563 ‚Äî Mathematical Statistics
MATH 563 ‚Äî Mathematical Statistics
text:
Approval ratings (cont‚Äôd)
If \(Y_1, \ldots, Y_n \IIDsim \Bern(\mu)\), then we can construct a confidence interval that captures the true approval rating with high probability:


\[\begin{align*}
T &:= Y_1 + \cdots + Y_n \sim \Bin(n,\mu), \quad \Prob(T = y) = \binom{n}{y} \mu^y (1-\mu)^{n-y}\\
\barY &:= \frac 1n (Y_1 + \cdots + Y_n) \appxsim  \Norm\bigl(\mu,\mu(1-\mu)/n\bigr) \quad \text{by the }\class{alert}{\text{Central Limit Theorem}} \\
95\% & \approx \Prob\Bigl[\mu - 1.96\sqrt{\mu(1-\mu)/n} \le \class{alert}{\barY} \le \mu + 1.96\sqrt{\mu(1-\mu)/n}\Bigr]
\end{align*}\]


\[\begin{align*}
T &:= Y_1 + \cdots + Y_n \sim \Bin(n,\mu), \quad \Prob(T = y) = \binom{n}{y} \mu^y (1-\mu)^{n-y}\\
\barY &:= \frac 1n (Y_1 + \cdots + Y_n) \appxsim  \Norm\bigl(\mu,\mu(1-\mu)/n\bigr) \quad \text{by the }\class{alert}{\text{Central Limit Theorem}} \\
95\% & \approx \Prob\Bigl[\mu - 1.96\sqrt{\mu(1-\mu)/n} \le \class{alert}{\barY} \le \mu + 1.96\sqrt{\mu(1-\mu)/n}\Bigr] \\
& = \Prob\Bigl[\barY - 1.96\sqrt{\mu(1-\mu)/n} \le \class{alert}{\mu} \le \barY + 1.96\sqrt{\mu(1-\mu)/n}\Bigr] \\
& \approx \Prob\Bigl[\barY - 1.96\sqrt{\barY(1-\barY)/n} \le \class{alert}{\mu} \le \barY + 1.96\sqrt{\barY(1-\barY)/n}\Bigr] \\
& \le \Prob\Bigl[\barY - 1/\sqrt{n} \le \class{alert}{\mu} \le \barY + 1/\sqrt{n} \Bigr] \quad \text{since } \sqrt{\barY(1-\barY)} \le 1/2
\end{align*}\]  For \(n = 1000\) we get \(1/\sqrt{n} \approx 3\%\).  ‚¨á Approval Rating Jupyter üìì
